results.title: Men like me
results.brief_description: “Men like me” is a collaboration between the filmmaker and Dale Michaels and was made in 1994 when female to male transgender was relatively unfamiliar to the broader community and rarely discussed. Informative and sensitively presented the film uses interviews, vox pops, archival footage and stills, combined with computer animated images and narration by Susan Long and Dale Michaels.

results.title: Memory of Christmas: from 'Act One' by Moss Hart
results.brief_description: A series of dramatic photographs illustrates playwright Moss Hart’s grievously impoverished childhood. The text, adapted from Hart’s autobiography “Act one” describes two Christmases a generation apart illustrating the gap that existed between himself and his father and how that gap was finally bridged.

results.title: Memento
results.creator_credit: Stefan Sharff and Centre for Mass Communication of Columbia University Press
results.brief_description: A fresh approach in the field of automobile safety, Memento uses picture and sound contrapuntally. Photographed in an automobile “graveyard”, the film presents a picture study of cars irreparably smashed in accidents, while the sound track reconstructs the voices of the participants of three particular accidents.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stefan Sharff and Centre for Mass Communication of Columbia University Press

results.title: Melodie En Sous-Sol = the Big Snatch (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
An ex-con sets up one last job and enlists the help of a younger crook to rob the Casino at Cannes. Everything goes according to plan, right up to the last minute until … A very standard caper film which gives one more opportunity to the trio Verneuil-Gabin-Audiard to send up the gangster genre with razor-sharp one-liners. Like his illustrious predecessors Henri Jeanson and Jacques Prevert, Audiard mixed classic French and slang and delighted in derision and ‘bons mots’, though his dialogue was coarser (a sign of the times) and more schocking. (…) Audiard’s witty, hard-hitting dialogue underpins much of the best popular French cinema from the late 1950s to the mid-1980s, notably his collaborations with Jean Gabin, for whom he wrote tailor-made dialogue.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The companion to French cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Juranville ; director, Henri Verneuil ; writers, Albert Simonin, Michel Audiard ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Michel Magne.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Alain Delon, Maurice Biraud, Viviane Romance, Henri Virlojeux, Germaine Montero, Jean Carmet, Dora Doll.

results.title: Melbourne's garden
results.brief_description: Colour studies of the Botanic Gardens; the many-coloured flowering shrubs, unending varieties of floral displays, shade of an oak lawn in summer, rockery plants providing brilliant colour, rose gardens with the newest varieties and the old favourites. The unusual foliage and blossoms to be found the Australian section; the delicate plant which flourish in the shelter of the glasshouses.

results.title: Meeting in session
results.creator_credit: Josef Bohmer and Columbia University Teahcer's College Bureau of Publications
results.brief_description: Glimpses of a variety of meetings - a school faculty, a high school committee, a business men’s session, a committee of nurses - illustrate the fact that most of us work in groups from time to time. Two contrasting session are presented, as a small group of nurses attempts to solve the problem of adequate staffing for the hospital four to twelve shift. In each meeting the problem and the participants are the same. The differences are in general approach, attitude displayed, techniques used and results achieved. In the first meeting participants enact negative roles characteristic of individuals intent on their own feelings and problems. The supervisor is an impatient administrator; head nurses demand rigid interpretation of present rules. In the second meeting nurses assume the roles of co-operative group members interested in desirable solutions and sympathetically aware of each other’s feelings. Each member contributes, and her ideas receive thoughtful consideration. At the end the nurse-recorder sums up suggestions, and each person volunteers for work on one or more specific proposals.

results.title: Meet the chief
results.creator_credit: Peter Hadingham, Boy Scouts Association (Great Britain) and Swift Films
results.brief_description: The Chief Scout, Sir Charles MacLean, in his home on the Isle of Mull. He is shown entertaining three Scouts and showing them over the castle where his ancestors have lived for centuries. The 1960 march past of Queen’s Scouts before Her Majesty at Windsor Castle; the Chief Scout’s speech on that occasion. Finally, a message from him to the Scouts of the Commonwealth.

results.title: Meet De Sica
results.creator_credit: Bika De Reisner, Christopher Leigh-Smith and Santa Lucia Productions
results.brief_description: An analysis of Vittorio De Sica, as director, actor, man; relaxed and informal, then occupied and businesslike. De Sica himself guides the narrative and introduces interesting sidelights from his intensively creative life. We learn much of De Sica’s ideas and methods from long detailed excerpts of his films, including Bread, Love and Dreams, Shoeshine, Bicycle Thieves, The Bed, Miracle in Milan.

results.title: Mediterranean climate of France
results.creator_credit: Centre Audio-Visuel and Les Films du Sagittaire
results.brief_description: Shows how the Mediterranean climate affects vegetation. The acute shortage of water in summer and the vital necessity for irrigation is shown, also characteristic villages and farmhouses and the grape harvest. Autumn is a time of violent storms punctuated with brief periods of sunshine enabling cultivation of crops and flowers to continue, in spite of the mistral winds of the season.
